in pencil in top margin  copy
letterhead       Telephone Monroe  1030     Chicago Commons   Grand Ave. and Morgan St.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
July 2d /32
My dear Mr Lawrence

           These protests against the indiscriminate charges that Federal bureaus and departmental service are wasteful and an imposition upon taxpayers, may interest you.

Too fast and too far are organized efforts being carried to reduce the excessive costs of government in demanding "slashing" economy, irrespective of essential values.   Even our Chicago Association of Commerce fails to disclaim the Chicago Tribune's attacks upon "Washington" as guilty of an  extortionate invasion of State rights, which in his radio alarms its publisher carries so far as to liken the aggressions of the National Government to the "Sacking of Rome by the Vandals! Psychopathic as this abberation [sic] is, it yet may so discredit the Federal government as to excite those who are losing their poise to acts of disloyalty. Indeed if so called Communists or

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

element_texts.text: Completed

other "reds" had used such language in their propaganda, it would have been regarded as seditious.

  The United States Daily furnishes the facts to Counteract this dangerous hysteria, which, unclear, need to be redistributed and interpreted to those whom it does not reach.

   This I am doing, as opportunity offers, in my Column in the Daily News - which is now rounding out its 30th year

element_texts.text: Completed

letterhead  Telephone Monroe 1030     Chicago Commons, Grand Ave. and Morgan St.
May 9, 1917
in pencil to left of letterhead    underlined:  Personal  in re health & our work
My dear Mr Lawson,

 It is too bad you are laid off from full duty these stirring times, but I am glad to learn that you are improving surely however slowly. 

You would have enjoyed meeting theFrench envoys.  They were a noble group of men - so simple and great.
The Daily News does great Service these days.  Just now its forth showing of the situation in Russia is most important.  Its dispatches are so much nearer the facts as I learn from my son's letters and from Mr. Lawrence?Houghpeling? who has just arrived from the scenes of the revolution in Petrograd. than the A.P. A  reports.
I am inclose a copy of Graham's last letter which gives an interesting glimpse of his eye witnessing. Please return it, as what he writes is semi-confidential.

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

element_texts.text: Completed

while he is connected with the U. S. embassy in Russia.
The oversight of the relief work for Germans interned in Russia undertaken by one Department of State has just been turned over to the Consuls of "Sweden"?.  This will change his plans, but how, I do not know.  I am glad Charles R. Crane is there to advise him.
Hoping for your complete and early recovery. I am.
Sincerely Your Friend.
Graham Taylor

955 Grand Avenue
Christmas Eve/1915
My Dear Dr Mock
This might have been a very different Christmas to us had it not been for your skillful, faithful Care of [[ Mr?Taylor..

Graham Taylor.

Harry E. Mock M.D.
122 S. Michigan Blvd
Chicago
Nov 4-54
Chicago
Miss Lea Taylor
Enclosed is your Fathers letter to me dated Xmas in 1914. It may not be suitable for this collection bu I think you might love it.
What a wonderful influence Graham Taylor was and still is in my life and how I love and cherish his memory.
Sincerely
Harry E. Mock
Original in Lea D. Taylor Series

element_texts.text: Completed

Mr  J B Pierce?
My dear Brother,
You may announce to the Communion and Congregation of the Fourth? Church, that after the most deliberate, thorough and prayerful consideration of the call to its pastorate, which with the concurrence of the Society, the Church has made upon me, I have been led to its acceptance, as I firmly believe, by the cloud?  of the Divine presence, which I am conscious of having followed. That the Lord whose I am, and whose you are may soon and always attest our mutual decision as His, own will?, by filling?]] His temple with the glory of His presence, and sending His Spirit to bear witness with ours? is the prayer of Your Servant for Jesus' Sake Hopewell? Parsonage 26th Mar 1880 Graham Taylor.

Fishers Island. New York
Aug. 11.1892.
My dear Prof.  Pratt?.
After a whole month's careful deliberation, throughout which I have not only been willing but? prayerfully Solcititons to be divinely led, I have decided that my single course of duty leads to the acceptance of the call to the Chicago Theological Seminary.  This conclusion I have reached today only after patiently waiting for and seeking after all the facts hearing upon? either side-

Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

weighing the considerations favoring each by themselves and dwelling upon a week at a time consecutively, Then after? calls ceased and we were alone by ourselves uninfluenced by either the presence of or by the unclear or communication from the representatives of any of the interests involved, we decided as best we could the single path of? duty.
My first inquiry was whether in the Seminarys  present situation I was warranted in considering any proposition to withdraw. I gave full weight to the urgent argument of those who decided that I had such warrant

In this unclear I unclear regret to disagree with some of my most unclear unclear and unclear unclear friends.  I cannot but think Their claim to be based upon a partial view of a temporary experience through? which the institution will safely pass to the successful prosecution of its own missions.

Mr Roger S. Roberts and the Hamilton County Nature Study Club Friends and Fellow Citizens [ unclear ] [Indians?] [,?]
A Citizen both so learned and so human as to know and interpret life -on- the [Wing?] in the [unclear], and also to understand and help liberate shut-in [lives?] of fellow men is [Indiana's?] great gift to all America

Graham Taylor

Telephone Monroe 1030
[corner handwritten comment - comment] Let friend Harry Wilson Share this please.]
Chicago Commons  
Grand Ave. and Morgan St.
Aug. 8/32
My Dear Mr [Roder?]
I have read with great interest and appreciation the Public Library's Report.  It registers many Signs of these times. to which attention should be called more widely.  I may devote my Daily News Editorial Column to this end. Will it be any more helpful, timely sooner or later?
I am especially interested in noting the great progress registered since the [branch?] and Station [unclear] and the children's work, began in 1906, the initiation of which I watched with great hope, while a [Director?]. You all have bravely labored under many shadows but have shed much light and cheer upon thousands depressed in spirit through these dreary years. Cordially Graham Taylor.

element_texts.text: Completed

Chicago Commons  955 West Grand Avenue Chicago, Illinois
Ravina, Illinois, June 19, 1937
My dear Carl Rodin, 

   I am so glad the library is off the relief list, yet you may welcome such contribution to your broken files of periodicals. I will be glad to send you what you have wanted and others that you may want if you will tell me how to send them and to whom to address them, whose attention you may call to our correspondence concerning them. I am making a clearance of accumulated back numbers, many of which are too valuable to discard.  While safeguarding my reading sight, I am relying upon my occultist's assurance that I may count upon it for fifteen more years.  Since I will be over one hundred before then, I am quite content. Wishing I could drop into see you once in a while as I cannot while tethered so closely out here in the Ravinia woods, I am hoping to keep in touch with you and your great work for us all in the public library.

Cordially yours, 
Graham Taylor
Please send me a list of what you have received from me.

element_texts.text: Completed

Chicago Commons
Telephone Monroe 1030   955 West Grand Avenue   Chicago, Illinois
Ravinia, Ill. 
Feb 8, 1938
1297 Wade St. Near Ry Station.
My [unclear] hears for me. I can [ unclear] mornings only
Mr. Carl B. Rodin:

     Several weeks ago, I half finished a Daily News Editorial in which I meant to follow up your celebration of the service rendered by the central building since its opening seventy- five years ago.  I have withheld it from publication until there might be some news value in playing up and developing the branch libraries and stations.  Your interesting statement of the failure to recover the large circulation of books and attendance of readers registered before the depression gives occasion for finishing and printing my plea for the cooperation of the people living near the branches and deposit stations.
    The increased income appropriated by the legislature to equip all deposits with new accessions to replace the worn out volumes in use until they were used up, and to complete the files of
periodicals the library subscriptions to which had to be suspended.

    There is much to encourage the peoples' cooperation with the library management in increasing the attraction and equipment of the branches and much in their depletion to account for the decreased circulation and attendance.

    Incidentally such encouragements wild include credits due to certain groups for their loyal courage during the long depression and for their cooperation in providing increased appropriations to the state library funds.  These groups include the staff, faithfully serving against great odds; the legislators who secured these increased appropriations; and the Legion and other organizations of veterans who might have still further embarrassed the critical situations by complaints the special privileges granted to them when the building funds were offered on condition that the great cental building should be erected as a memorial to the veterans of the Civil War.

    I should hope that these facts to be stated and these credits to be cited would forstall any criticism which has been so loyally withheld.  But I should be put wise as to the delicacy involved in paying each of these tributes.

    To this end I need the cautionary advice of yourself and Mr. Wilson.  Were I able to move about I would seek an immediate interview with both of you at the Library.  But since my weak hear forbids any such risks I must depend upon both of you either to run out here to see me for an hour's interview or fully advise me so that I may be helpfully encouraging and in   no respect harmful in what should be my next editorial in the Daily News.  Let me now at once what help I my promptly expect from you and greatly oblige your fellow director of long ago and your comrade in the good fellowship of our public Library service.

Graham Taylor

element_texts.text: Completed

Telephone Monroe 1030                                                                                                 Taylor Graham
Chicago Commons, Grand Ave. and Morgan Street
May 13/31
My dear Mr [Rosewald?],
[unclear] birthday greeting, red by Mr [Friedman?] to my comrades of the [M.V. L ?] and other civic groups at the Standard club on May [2nd?] went straight to my heart as it came from [unclear].
That you and other fellow citizens should feel indebted for anything I have [been?] or done surprises me, as my retrospect registers only such responses to obligation and opportunity as a citizen should make, for his city's sake not only, but for his own sake.  And am well aware how much I owe to Chicago for making me over and bring me hitherto. 
What you have all along been to your city and done with and for your fellow citizens have exemplified a citizenship that inspires me and my fellow residents at Chicago Commons to live and work between all dividing lines for the common good.
Regretting so much your illness and hoping ardently for your speedy restoration to your great field of action, 
Gratefully and cordially your friend
Grahan Taylor

Hartford Theological Seminary.
Founded in 1834
Hartford Conn, 
August 17, 1892
The Rev, G, S, F, Savage. DD.
Secretary of the board of Directors of the Chicago Theological Seminary.
My dear Sir.
After the most deliberate and  prayerful consideration of the call [preoffered?] me by the Executive Committee of your Board to the professorship of Christain Sociology and the English Bible in the Chicago Theological Seminary, I am at last [irresistibly?] [constrained?] to accept it.  For a whole month the two peculiarly inspiring fields of usefulness were [strangely?] kept open before me.  I could decide for neither, until a single course of duty was disclosed to me.  For this I waited long, but not

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

element_texts.text: Completed

in vain.  It required most of this time to assure myself that I could honestly, honorably and safely relinquish that Stewardship which God had [ unclear] entrusted to me here for four years in the Seminary and for twelve years in the church and the city.  This was a peculiarly difficult and trying experience, not only because of the exceptionally vital personal relationships by which my heart was bound to the very diverse spheres in which I had lived and labored so long, but also because so many public institutions and interests were seriously involved in my decision.

When, however, It became clear that I must choose between the opportunities for service afforded by each field in order to decide to which of them the Master called me, I clearly recognized His voice in the [juncture of two plainly Providential?] indications.  Ten years ago I had been led by a new

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

element_texts.text: Completed

Hartford Theological Seminary Founded 1834
Hartford Conn., 189
consciousness of the needs of my fellow men [unclear inserted line] to devote my life to the single purpose, which has ever since possessed it, [unclear] to apply our common Christianity to common life and its social conditions.  
That was the first indication of duty. The other is the opening of the largest possible opportunity for the fulfillment of this purpose, under conditions peculiarly adapted to those very aptitudes for service in which the greater efficiency has [unclear] in here and the [unclear] attestations of divine approval have been [unclear].  Thies opportunity I also believe the Chicago Theological Seminary has been enabled to afford me by a strangely Providential combination of conditions, such as exist in no other Seminary or city.  In this juncture of my life's purpose and your most exceptional opportunity for its surest and largest fulfillment,

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

element_texts.text: Completed

I recognize and dare not disobey the voice of God.  Let me assure you however, as I already have the people of the Fourth church and my associates in the Board of Trustees and Faculty of the Hartford Seminary, that no other opportunity which I can conceive of could I have been led to think it my duty to leave the field for [unclear]they afford me, and at so great wide  [I am of heart?] as it costs to sever relationships such as identity my very life with church, seminary and city.
This fact may also attest the unreserved confidence I [unclear] in the Board of Trustees and their Executive Committee, to whose loyalty to the Kingdom I now implicitly trust, my own service in it and all my ministry and brotherhood among men.  That is reciprocal confidence may never be [unclear] I accompany my acceptance which is to take effect Oct 1 [1893?] with a statement of my understanding of the assurance which have been minor factors of my decision.
Faithfully and Fraternally yours  
Graham Taylor
